In Tanzania, the national home-based care cadre and other lay workers (i.e. community health workers or CHWs) play various support roles within the HIV continuum of care. In particular, these cadres facilitate early enrollment in and retention in care, as well as provide clients with support for disclosure of their status, educate PLHIV about living with the virus, and provide treatment adherence support.
The impact CHWs have on improving health outcomes is well documented, primarily within the maternal and child health literature. However, there is little evidence in Tanzania about the impact of community health and lay workers in HIV care. PEPFAR/T will address this gap through an evaluation of the impact that these workers have on linkage to and retention in care as well as describe how the client experience impacts care enrollment and retention.
At the time of COP preparation, the evaluation regions and sites had not been identified. However, the sites will be chosen based on a variety of factors including facility client load, local government engagement and epidemiological and demographic considerations.
PEPFAR/T will utilize the Supporting Operational AIDS Research Project (Project SOAR) mechanism to serve as the research partner for this evaluation titled “Impact of community health workers and lay counselors on linkage and retention in HIV/AIDS care in the United Republic of Tanzania.” Project SOAR aims to support and advance implementation of global HIV programming through operational research and evaluation assistance, and findings to further the public purpose of informing the global evidence base for addressing the HIV epidemic. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. objectives
